reviewText:
The third season of Sam & Max represents a shift in tone and gameplay. The changes are obvious from the very beginning - a narrator to set the scene, new control scheme (same as Tales of Monkey Island; clearly favouring consoles), a new villain, an opening tutorial of sorts (which is so entertaining and interactive that it puts most other tutorials to shame), psychic powers for Max and a grainier, darker graphical style.

It may sound like a lot of changes to a successful formula, but it works well. Not only does it provide a quite accessible introduction for newcomers to the series (including clever little pop-up profiles of characters and notes in a journal about the case and clues), but it also provides a fresh spin on the series for veterans.

Of course, the series lives or dies by the writing and puzzles, and thankfully both are still strong. The new villain, Skunkape, is wonderfully voiced and a highly entertaining character. A few old favourites are missing, while others return (as well as some who are not quite favourites; the Stinky clan seem only slightly more popular than the late, unlamented Soda Poppers…). There are some wonderful lines, with even more smashing of the fourth wall than usual – a few particularly good remarks about non-player characters, for instance.

Puzzles are made a little more interesting through Max's future vision, which offers a glimpse of dialogue from a later scene. It's generally relevant to a puzzle at a particular location, and offers an idea of what to do without giving too much away. Another power, teleportation, saves a lot of the tedious trekking around, which is especially useful as load times seem a little longer than previous games. There's also a bit of a change in mindset with collecting items; they're no longer all directly used for puzzles, with some being clues to unlock new locations. Those new locations look quite similar to the old ones (lampshaded by Max), but at least offer a bit of a feeling about a wider gameworld.

There's a few scripting oddities, with certain events not triggering when they are supposed to (the intended initial teleport scene, for instance, didn't come up for me until quite late in the game because I chose something they apparently didn't expect the first time), but other than that the game seems to work well.

The episode is probably the most promising start to a Sam and Max season yet, and with the tease of more powers to come, and hints at future storylines, there's a lot to draw a player into the following episodes.

reviewText: Twisted, strange, and genuinely entertaining, this is a welcome continuation of the series, with some oddly emotional moments. Expect the same kind of mind-screwing puzzles, but more perplexing and yet more reasonable than ever before. Hints generally feel organic and a natural part of conversation, and things you've likely come to expect from adventure games are ruthlessly mocked and subverted. There's really no telling where the story goes next, but when it does go there, it feels as though you really did have proper warning, and it doesn't just come out of left field. Some moments do end up turning into pixel hunting, but it's far, far more rare than other recent adventure games. The ending is, well, notable. I'd say I'm most impressed by the much different nature of Episode 2, but you'll see that when you get to it. The game certainly knows when to be serious and when to loosen up, and swings between the two at an excellent rate. In short, a truly engaging puzzle game with plenty of laughs, but keep some brain bleach on hand.

reviewText: Wow...just, wow. Even I'm blown away, and I thought I knew what to expect. The only way to describe it is what Serenity was to Firefly: a continuation of the same story but with much higher production values. The camera seems to have an actual film quality now, the scenes shadow, and the characters feel more like claymation (my PC actually shuddered a bit at the reqs, but if anything this subtle stagger only makes them seem even more like stop motion puppets.) They've added so many things that will make you grin from ear to ear when you realize. Two things, though. The movement controls are worse since this was the first game really meant for console controllers: it's annoying but serviceable. Secondly, as before, you *really* need to play through the earlier seasons first. The overall characters and plot keep pushing forward, and you'll be completely lost without past events to hold onto. But this might just be the best adventure game I've ever played.

Sam & Max gets darker in this third season. Each episode takes on a different storytelling genre like sci-fi, adventure, and Lovecraftian horror, but still packed with the witty banter and puzzles of previous Sam & Max games.

The first thing I should point out are the controls. Rather than clicking on where you want Sam to go like in Seasons 1 and 2 (and pretty much every other P&C Adventure), you click and drag, essentially creating an analog stick with your cursor. Oh, and Max has psychic powers now. New to S&M (wait, that sounded wrong) are toys. No seriously. Now Max can teleport (but only to people's telephones that he has the number to), there's a ViewMaster that lets him see the future, and a ventriloquist dummy that lets him throw his voice. But some other people are after The Devil's Toybox, and it evolves into something bigger than in the previous seasons.

If you've already enjoyed the previous S&M games, pick this one up and finish the trilogy.

reviewText: Another solid Sam and Max season.  Great presentation via an Alfred Hitchcock-esque narrator and some cool new gameplay elements. Any fan of point and click adventures, Lucas Arts adventure games, or good comedy games should play all three of these seasons, they are all very well done and very much worthe the playthrough.

It's really good.  After finishing The Devil's Playhouse I went back and played the previous two seasons because I enjoyed this one so much. Both of those combined are about as good as TDP.  There's a really good mechanic where Max develops supernatural powers where he can look into the future and morph into different objects, and can teleport to different locations, along with other abilities using toys from the infernal Devil's Toy Chest. There are a lot of creative ideas employed  throughout the episodes. The humor can be a bit sophomoric at times and some of the jokes fall flat, but overall there's a lot of good jokes  and the story goes all over the place and is sufficiently epic. Not quite as good as Tales from Monkey Island, but it's still another gem from Telltale games and I definitely highly recommend!

I got this as a part of the Humble Bundle and decided to go back and play the others so I could get some context. Sadly, playing those games added very little context as this game is grounded in complete absurdity, as are the previous titles. Still, I enjoyed every mind melting minute of all of them and this one is easily my favorite. The controls are a bit wonky to start but you get used to them, and the writing is absolutely at its best. And, even though the game is complete batshit insanity at all times, it actually made me feel for the characters involved. At times I actually felt sad for Sam and Max. Actual, real emotions for two characters that have no regard for the feelings of anyone or anything around them.\n\nOh and for anyone wondering about the length of the season, it's roughly 2-3 hours per episode if you aren't an absolute master at these games and maybe only 1.5 hours if you are. I'm okay at puzzle games like this but due to the complete lack of sanity in the puzzles, some solutions stumped me. Basically, you're looking at 7.5 - 15 hours total which is a decent chunk more than the previous titles.
